Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Scalable Volume-NanoManufacturing of Unique Nanoparticles by Nano-templated Printing, Deposition, and Exfoliation for Energy and Bio/Chemical Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
To have the best possible performance in a given application, nanoparticles must be manufactured with uniform size and precise shape, structure and composition. This Scalable NanoManufacturing (SNM) award supports an innovative approach to attaining such uniformity in the manufacturing of a new class of energy conversion phosphor nanoparticles. This approach, termed "nanoprint by templated exfoliateable deposition" (n-PrinTED), is fundamentally different from traditional chemical synthesis. The new method uses a template and potentially enables the production of a broad range of nanoparticle types applicable to a wide range of fields and industries, including bio/chemical sensing, solid state lighting, displays, batteries, and fuel cells. The success of the research will benefit U.S. competitiveness and leadership in nanotechnology and aid U.S industry, leading to significant economic impact.

To overcome the key challenges in nanoparticle fabrication, this new method, n-PrinTED, fabricates nanoparticles (NPs) by using a template to restrict material deposition/reaction, which regulates the materials' (hence the final NP's) shape and location, rather than a "free-form" reaction; and n-PrinTED also opens up a broad range of new possibilities in deposition methods, materials choices, and processing/reaction conditions and sequences. Therefore, n-PrinTED offers many new ways to fabricate NPs with unique shapes, structures, and compositions (hence properties) that are unachievable by current methods. n-PrinTED can thus be used for a broad range of new nanoparticles. The project will focus on the application of n-PrinTED in new NPs for efficient up/down conversion of energy and will take an approach that integrates a broad range of disciplines and knowledge.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has successfully accomplished two major goals, (a) development of new low-cost large area nanopatterning methods based on nanoimprint and nanoprint, and exploration their applications, in particular high sensitivity bio-sensing; and (b) development of a low cost and high yield nanomaterial (e.g. nanoparticles) synthesis method for energy conversion.

The highlights of key achievements of the project are:

(1)   We proposed and experimentally demonstrated a new, direct synthesis method for NaYF4:Yb, Er upconversion nanoparticles using nanoimprinted periodic structures as a template, termed Nanopatterned-mesh-Assisted In-situ Decomposition (NAISD) method. Using this method with different mesh templates, we have synthesized NaYF4:Yb, Er upconversion nanoparticles with average particle size of 557nm and 375nm, respectively. Photophysical experiments show that the resulting particles have improved upconversion efficiency and luminescence properties compared with particles synthesized by in-solution thermolysis method. Mechanisms of particle formation in the NAISD method were investigated by in-situ observation of particle formation process at various temperatures using a hot stage in an environmental scanning electron microscope (ESEM) with various precursor ratios. It is found that the Na/Ln ratio and melting temperature of the precursor salts have a significant impact on the morphology of the nanoparticles synthesized by using the NAISD method.

(2)   New nanoplasmonic structures and manufacturing, and their ultra-high sensitivity biosensing.  We have developed and investigated the manufacturing and applications of several new nanostructures in ultra-high sensitivity biosensing, particularly, a new nanoplasmonic structure,  M-plate (also termed D2PA (Disk-coupled Dots on Pillar Array)).  The M-Plate assay platform, invented in PI’s lab, uses a plasmonic nanostructured surface to drastically amplify the signal of optical label in an assay (either protein or nucleic acid assays). The M-Plate can amplify the signal of single molecular fluorophore by orders of magnitude, leading to single molecule detection and pixilated reading (i.e. “digital reading”), significantly reduce the noise and increase signal, and hence ultra-high detection sensitivity. We have successfully achieved, compared with conventional assays, over four orders of magnitude sensitivity improvements (e.g. 5X10^4) for brain injury biomarkers, and over five orders of magnitude sensitivity improvements (e.g. 220 fg/ml sensitivity, and an enhancement factor of 2X10^5) for Ebola biomarkers.

(3)   A flame synthesis approach for producing metal oxide nanoparticles is developed. It is based on a novel microjet atomisation technique which generates solution aerosol droplets in the sub-micron range with a mean diameter of 200 nm. Using this method, luminescent Eu-doped Y2O3 nanophosphors are successfully synthesised from aqueous metal nitrate precursors delivered to non-premixed CH4/O2/N2 flames. A generic diagram of particle formation from aerosol synthesis is obtained. At high temperature, the droplet vaporization is so fast that all liquid is transformed to gas phase and forms ultrafine nanoparticles. However, at low temperature, the droplet vaporization is so slow that the precursor diffusion is fast so that it results in a single droplet to single particle formation pathway. At an intermediate temperature, the solvent vaporization rate is faster than the precursor precipitates, it results in a hollow particles. The present method provides a new platform and new mechanism to control particle size for the synthesis of energy materials.

(4)   We conducted the synthesis of high nickel cobalt and manganese oxide  LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) Li-ion battery cathode materials using an aerosol of micron-size aqueous metal nitrate solution droplets delivered to non-premixed flames. The effect of Ni mole fraction and the aerosol preheating and flame synthesis temperatures on the particle properties and electrochemistry by comparing NCM811 with LiNi0.33Co0.33Mn0.33O2 (NCM111) was investigated.  It is also found that aerosol preheating and flame temperatures play critical roles in determining the electrochemical properties of the final annealed product. The present study shows that aerosol synthesis offers multiple ways to control the length- and timescales over which transport processes occur. This opens up possibilities to tailor the morphology and compositional gradients and thereby improve the cycle lifetime of Ni-rich materials.

(5)  Controlled dysprosium (Dy) doping to NCM811 was studied in an aerosol synthesis method by controlling the precursor concentrations and heating parameters. The results showed that the particle morphology is strongly determined by the ratio of solvent evaporation time to solute diffusion time. It also showed that the cycle ability and high-rate performances of the Dy-doped NCM811 electrode were significantly improved. The Dy materials exhibited an excellent rate capability, delivering initial discharge capacities of 199.4 mAh g-1 with capacity retentions of 174 mAh % at 5C, respectively, with the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V after 50 cycles. The thermal-chemical stability analysis in a flow reactor showed that Dy doped cathode materials shifted the O2 onset temperature to a higher temperature and reduced O2 release by 80%, thus dramatically increased the thermal-chemicals stability and improved the fire safety of cathode materials. The work have broad implications for commercial synthesis of novel materials with controlled doping modification to achieve high performance and safe lithium ion batteries.


Last Modified: 03/10/2021
Modified by: Stephen Y Chou
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project has successfully accomplished two major goals, (a) development of new low-cost large area nanopatterning methods based on nanoimprint and nanoprint, and exploration their applications, in particular high sensitivity bio-sensing; and (b) development of a low cost and high yield nanomaterial (e.g. nanoparticles) synthesis method for energy conversion. The highlights of key achievements of the project are: (1) We proposed and experimentally demonstrated a new, direct synthesis method for NaYF4:Yb, Er upconversion nanoparticles using nanoimprinted periodic structures as a template, termed Nanopatterned-mesh-Assisted In-situ Decomposition (NAISD) method. Using this method with different mesh templates, we have synthesized NaYF4:Yb, Er upconversion nanoparticles with average particle size of 557nm and 375nm, respectively. Photophysical experiments show that the resulting particles have improved upconversion efficiency and luminescence properties compared with particles synthesized by in-solution thermolysis method. It is found that the Na/Ln ratio and melting temperature of the precursor salts have a significant impact on the morphology of the nanoparticles synthesized by using the NAISD method. We have developed and investigated the manufacturing and applications of several new nanostructures in ultra-high sensitivity biosensing, particularly, a new nanoplasmonic structure, M-plate (also termed D2PA (Disk-coupled Dots on Pillar Array)). The M-Plate assay platform, invented in PIâ€™s lab, uses a plasmonic nanostructured surface to drastically amplify the signal of optical label in an assay (either protein or nucleic acid assays). The M-Plate can amplify the signal of single molecular fluorophore by orders of magnitude, leading to single molecule detection and pixilated reading (i.e. "digital reading"), significantly reduce the noise and increase signal, and hence ultra-high detection sensitivity. (3) A flame synthesis approach for producing metal oxide nanoparticles is developed. At an intermediate temperature, the solvent vaporization rate is faster than the precursor precipitates, it results in a hollow particles. The present method provides a new platform and new mechanism to control particle size for the synthesis of energy materials. (4) We conducted the synthesis of high nickel cobalt and manganese oxide LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) Li-ion battery cathode materials using an aerosol of micron-size aqueous metal nitrate solution droplets delivered to non-premixed flames. The effect of Ni mole fraction and the aerosol preheating and flame synthesis temperatures on the particle properties and electrochemistry by comparing NCM811 with LiNi0.33Co0.33Mn0.33O2 (NCM111) was investigated. The results showed that the particle morphology is strongly determined by the ratio of solvent evaporation time to solute diffusion time. It also showed that the cycle ability and high-rate performances of the Dy-doped NCM811 electrode were significantly improved. The Dy materials exhibited an excellent rate capability, delivering initial discharge capacities of 199.4 mAh g-1 with capacity retentions of 174 mAh % at 5C, respectively, with the cutoff voltage of 4.3 V after 50 cycles. The thermal-chemical stability analysis in a flow reactor showed that Dy doped cathode materials shifted the O2 onset temperature to a higher temperature and reduced O2 release by 80%, thus dramatically increased the thermal-chemicals stability and improved the fire safety of cathode materials. The work have broad implications for commercial synthesis of novel materials with controlled doping modification to achieve high performance and safe lithium ion batteries.
